info.game_comments:
2003 Back to School Week game 3.
Game data retrieved from an alternate archive.

(1, 1).clue: In September 1992 Mae Jemison blasted off aboard this as the first African-American woman in space

(2, 1).clue: Try to spend a full day exploring the Mayan ruins of Chichen Itza when you visit this country

(3, 1).clue: The tricuspid valve in this organ keeps blood in the right ventricle from flowing back into the right atrium

(4, 1).clue: Rerun is Linus' little brother in this comic strip

(5, 1).clue: In 1620 it took this ship 66 days to sail from England to Massachusetts

(6, 1).clue: This word is the same in singular or plural, so Dr. Seuss was correct when he wrote "One" This "Two" This

(1, 2).clue: In 1961 Fred Moore stood watch as the first black guard at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in this cemetery

(2, 2).clue: You'll see giraffes up close if you stay at Giraffe Manor in this African country that starts with the letter "k"

(3, 2).clue: The thick, triangular deltoid muscle, which allows the arm to be raised, covers this joint

(4, 2).clue: In 2003 this lasagna-loving cat celebrated his 25th anniversary as a comic strip character

(5, 2).clue: Guinness says the longest one of these very chilly periods on Earth lasted 70 million years

(6, 2).clue: The plural of house isn't hice, as you might think when you learn this rodent plural

(1, 3).clue: From 1969 to 1983 Shirley Chisholm served New York state in this U.S. Gov't. body that elects its members every 2 years

(2, 3).clue: If you're at least 39" tall, you can ride the Mountain Slidewinder at this Dolly Parton theme park

(3, 3).clue: A dilator muscle enlarges this part of the eye to allow more light in

(4, 3).clue: This Great Dane lives with Dottie, Phil, Barbara & Billy Winslow

(5, 3).clue: I get tired just walking to the fridge, so I'm not going to attempt a marathon, a run just over this many miles

(6, 3).clue: The "s" may not go where you think in this plural for the wives of your brothers

(1, 4).clue: Now a member of President Bush's Cabinet, this Army man is the son of Jamaican immigrants

(3, 4).clue: The lower leg consists of 2 bones: the tibia & this slightly smaller one

(4, 4).clue: In a Mike Peters comic strip, Attila is Mother Goose's cat; he's Mother Goose's dog

(6, 4).clue: Disney popularized one plural for these little people; Tolkien preferred another one

(1, 5).clue: Chemist Lloyd Quarterman worked on the 1940s "Manhattan Project" & helped build the first of these weapons

(3, 5).clue: In addition to producing insulin, this organ produces digestive juices used to break down food

(6, 5).clue: "Tooth" & this part at the other end of your body form plurals by changing their interior vowel sound

(1, 1).clue: Nuclear decay in some atoms can cause the emission of this in the form of alpha & beta particles or gamma rays

(2, 1).clue: Developed in the mid-19th century, it's the communication "code" that uses dots & dashes

(3, 1).clue: He was the top vote getter in the electoral college of 1789

(4, 1).clue: Don't have a cow, man! Nancy Cartwright (yep, a woman) is the voice of this animated bad boy

(5, 1).clue: Traditionally, 2 male dancers play the wicked stepsisters in this ever-popular fairy tale ballet

(6, 1).clue: On the internet, this vowel can precede "zine", "commerce", "mail" & "bay"

(1, 2).clue: The Chilean & Puna species of this large pink bird live in the Andes

(3, 2).clue: Moving to D.C. in 1800, this judicial body met in the Capitol basement, a library office & a tavern

(4, 2).clue: Cable network on which the visual seen here happens on a regular basis

(5, 2).clue: The famous 1938 ballet about a western outlaw is named for this "kid", not the Sundance Kid

(6, 2).clue: In names of kings & queens, this vowel represents "the first"

(1, 3).clue: The lowest point of a wave is the trough; this is the highest point of a wave

(2, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew presents in front of a blackboard.)  The word "Jeopardy!" is expressed in this ancient system of writing, whose name comes from a term meaning "sacred carving"

(3, 3).clue: In 1813 Major Armistead ordered one of these for Fort McHenry so large that the enemy could see it easily from afar

(4, 3).clue: In this series' 2001 premiere episode, Clark Kent saved the life of budding entrepreneur Lex Luthor

(5, 3).clue: Robert Atwood choreographed a ballet about this "apprentice" that Mickey Mouse played in "Fantasia"

(6, 3).clue: This type of "boat" is what Germans call submarines

(1, 4).clue: This invertebrate phylum includes squids, octopusses, clams & mussels

(2, 4).clue: The homing or carrier type of this bird has been used to carry messages for 2,000 years

(3, 4).clue: In March 1804 Lewis & Clark were in this city ready to leave on their expedition when it became part of the U.S.

(4, 4).clue: Scott Bakula captains a straship called this a century before Captain Kirk does the same

(5, 4).clue: After seeing this classic Christmas ballet, you'll have visions of the Sugar Plum Fairy dancing in your head

(6, 4).clue: The capital city of Alaska ends with these 3 vowels

(1, 5).clue: Hydrogen means "water forming" & this means "sharp forming" (It was thought it formed acids)

(2, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew presents.)  Abbreviated "ASL", it's the language I'm using to do my ABC's

(3, 5).clue: The people who guided runaway slaves along the Underground Railroad were called these

(4, 5).clue: You can watch "Charmed" on this network whose spokesfrog wears a top hat

(6, 5).clue: The 2 vowels that are used to designate a major human blood group

(0, 0).clue: The opening to this classic story includes the line "Once upon a time there was a piece of wood"
